p.s: Considering that this excerpt marks the point at which Gatsby and Daisy reunite after almost five years of seperationseparation, it is very pertinent to the story as it evolves since Gatsby's love for Daisy is one of the main topics of the novel.
To Gatsby, being with Daisy means happiness and this is what he pursues, which this excerpt shows clearly.
Furthermore, it reveals a side of him which is new to the reader.
First of all, as Nick and Daisy enter the living room, Gatsby who has previously been there is gone to knock, just a second later, on the door in a light, dignified way (p. 84, l. 13).
This is how the first-person-narrator Nick, from his viewpoint perspective describes it.

That already shows that Gatsby wants to keep his dignity in front of his beloved and impress her with his appearance, but the light slightly hints at his nervousness which makes him careful and hesitant to knock.
He is obviously trying to overcome it.
He could have, in fact, stayed in the living room and met Daisy there directly, but he goes outside to come back in instead.
It can be assumed he chose to do so rather than staying to rid himself of his nervousness and to become calmer.
Whether this surprises Nick or not can't be said surely because he exaggerates his statement To my overwhelming surprise (p. 84, l. 9f.) so much that it seems ironic.
As Gatsby enters the house, he is pale as death (p. 84, l. 14) and is glaring tragically (l. 16) into Nick's eyes.
Furthermore his hands are plunged like weights (l. 15) in his pockets which might be an attempt at trying to hide their shaking.

Comparing Gatsby's face with deaddeath and thereby putting his actual appearance in a stark contrast to his dignified knocking conveys how he is internally in turmoil whereas on the outside he is trying hard to remain calm and to control his emotions.
However this seems exaggerated considering how it is simply a meeting with the woman he loves expecting him.
Thus it reflects on just how anxious Gatsby must be.
Since it has been long since they last met and she is now married, he might fear that she does not love him anymore and will refuse to speak to him.
It shows his insecurity and the fragility of his self-confidence as well as of their bond.
Given Daisy's reaction when they meet, she is thrown aback by the confrontation as well.
For a while, the three of them are just feeling awkward, especially Nick although he is not really connected to their realationshiprelationship.
Daisy at first, speaks in a clear artificial note (p. 84, l. 23) which makes her seem like the one who has better control over herself.
It might as well be an attempt to gain time to think of a reaction.
She remains seated while Gatsby tries to look calm and confident like the usual version of himself he shows at parties etc. e.g. by leaning against a shelve, hands in his pockets.
He tries to laugh (p. 85, l. 4) but is totoo stiff to do so.
Nick and Gatsby do not know what to say, so he says something as trivial as I'm sorry about the clock (p. 85, l. 9) to overcome the awkwardness.
Again, Daisy steps in and remarks that Gatsby and her have not met for many years (l. 15f.), however due to Nick she says it matter-of-factly.
Thereby the reader can see it is hard for the two of them to open up which is probably due to Nick's presence.
That is why he wants to leave when Gatsby takes him into the kitchen to talk in private and lets his emotions out (l. 30f.).
Upon realizing through Nick telling him, that Daisy is just as nervous and embarassed as him Gatsby is surprised.
Not realizing that others feel the same way as oneself is usually something that occurs with immature, young persons.
However Gatsby has behaved quite mature up until now, although it seemed staged especially when he told Nick about his past.
It furthermore signifies that a person is only focused on herself and does not pay attention to others.
Gatsby has even been observing Nick and Daisy for a while from a shadow (p. 85, l. 23) while they have been talking, looking very unpleased (see p. 85, l. 24-25).
And yet he did not notice Daisy's embarassment.
Hence he must have been absent-minded.
Thus when Nick tells him about it and he repeated incredulously (p. 86, l. 5) that she is embarassed, it seems as if he is awakening from a trance.
Nick becomes impatient and tells him he behaves childish which makes him come to his senses at last.
The image of Gatsby that Nick draws here is that of a childish, insecure and immature man with a lot of wealth and love for Daisy.
He is behaving like a teenager on a first date which stands significantly in contrast to the image created of him before and immediately after meeting him.
Nick then leaves them alone and when he returns, Gatsby's situation has become much better.
He has gone through a change which Nick illustrates really vividly.
Gatsby'snew well-being radiated from him and filled the little room(p. 87 ll. 5f.).
The imagery used here is such a vivid description that it makes him vibrant to the reader and one can feel what is being described here.
At first glance it might be assumed that he seems like his old self again but if you look closer, Gatsby is now even more vibrant and happy thenthan before.
This side of him is only made visible thanks to Daisy's appearance since she is what he has been pursuing.
Anyhow, he is paying less attention to Nick now, greeting him as if he hadn't seen him in a long time thus as if he had completely forgotten about him (see p. 87 l. 16).
When Gatsby tells Daisy the weather has become better, she responds I'm glad, Jay (l. 23), but looking at her emotional state she must mean their reunion rather than the weather.
Furthermore, calling him by his surname Jay indicates their intimate relationship.
The antithesis Her throat, full of aching, grieving beauty told only of her unexpected joy (p. 87 l. 23f.), shows Daisy's sudden burst of contradictory emotions.
On the one side, there is the accumulation aching, grieving along with the personification of her beauty which tells of her pain and makes her come alifealive to reader.
On the other side, there is joy which is positive.
Thus in this case, her pain is connotated positively and shows the hardships Daisy has endured alone with Tom, seperatedseparated from Gatsby.
Yet it was her decision not to wait for him.
Eventually, Gatsby wants to take Nick and Daisy to see his house.
Here there is a hint at his deceptive, bragful side.
He wants to impress Daisy with his wealth to win her back.
Even though due to Nick's viewpoint perspective one can notcannot take his narration as objection and factbased, it is not bad to have him as narrator here.
The author deliberately uses vivid, impressionistic descriptions to give a somewhat tangible impression of what is happening rather than objective reality which could seem too dry.
That way he is able to characterize Gatsby so detailed and comprehensible, especially at the end.
Gatsby is first displayed as immature and insecure, then, however, as glowing, vibrant and content.
